Sure, here's a lesson plan on colors for 5 to 7-year-olds:

Title: Exploring Colors
Objective: Students will be able to identify and name primary and secondary colors and explore mixing colors to create new shades.

Materials:

* Color wheel poster or printout
* White paper
* Paint or colored markers
* Paintbrushes or markers

Introduction:
Introduce the concept of colors by asking the students to name their favorite colors. Show them a color wheel and explain that colors can be divided into primary colors (red, blue, and yellow) and secondary colors (orange, green, and purple).

Activity 1: Identifying Colors
Give each student a sheet of white paper and a set of markers or paints. Ask them to color the paper with the primary colors and the secondary colors. As they work, ask them to identify the colors they are using.

Activity 2: Mixing Colors
Explain to the students that by mixing primary colors, they can create secondary colors. Give each student a new sheet of white paper and ask them to mix the primary colors to create secondary colors. For example, ask them to mix red and yellow to create orange. Encourage them to experiment with different ratios of colors to create different shades.

Activity 3: Color Hunt
Hide small items of different colors around the classroom or outside. Ask the students to find the items and match them to the corresponding color on the color wheel.

Conclusion:
Review the primary and secondary colors with the students and ask them to name some objects that are those colors. Ask them if they enjoyed exploring colors and if they learned something new.

Assessment:
To assess the students' understanding of the lesson, you can ask them to do the following:

1. Ask the students to point out the primary colors and the secondary colors on the color wheel.
2. Show them a picture of an object and ask them to name the color of the object.
3. Ask the students to mix two primary colors to create a secondary color.

Extension:
To extend the lesson, you can have the students create a color wheel of their own. Give them a blank circle and ask them to divide it into six equal parts. Label each part with a primary or secondary color and have them color each part accordingly.

You can also introduce the concept of warm and cool colors and ask them to create a painting using only warm or cool colors. This will help them understand the emotional impact of colors and how they can be used to express different moods and feelings.

Overall, this lesson plan is designed to introduce the concept of colors to young children and help them understand the basics of primary and secondary colors, mixing colors, and identifying colors in everyday objects. It is a fun and interactive way to engage children in learning and promote their creativity and imagination.
